instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances?
Output: In the related study for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances, several types of spectra were used. These include one-dimensional infrared (1D-IR) spectra, synchronous two-dimensional correlation infrared (2D-IR) spectra, asynchronous two-dimensional correlation infrared (2D-IR) spectra, and RGB IR-images.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed in the related study for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods employed in the related study for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances were one-dimensional infrared (1D-IR), synchronous and asynchronous two trace two-dimensional correlation infrared (2T-2DCOS-IR), as well as their RGB IR-image.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the developed models in the related study for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances, and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the developed models in the related study for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances was accuracy. The study reported that the asynchronous MM-IR-AlexNet (2T-2DCOS-IR-AlexNet) model achieved a 99.6% accuracy. Therefore, the chosen metric of accuracy was able to assess the performance of the models with a high level of precision.

instruction: What machine learning algorithms were compared to the developed MM-IR-AlexNet flour models in the related study for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances?
Output: The machine learning algorithms that were compared to the developed MM-IR-AlexNet flour models in the study were not specified in the given text.

instruction: Can the deep learning-based MM-IR method, specifically the asynchronous MM-IR-AlexNet, be used as a superior alternative to traditional methods for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances?
Output: Yes, the deep learning-based MM-IR method, specifically the asynchronous MM-IR-AlexNet, can be used as a superior alternative to traditional methods for the direct identification of flour with diverse harmful substances. The study mentioned in the text demonstrated that the asynchronous MM-IR-AlexNet had the best performance with 99.6% accuracy in identifying target substances in flour. This indicates that the deep learning-based MM-IR method is a robust and accurate approach for the direct detection of trace harmful substances in flour.
